DOC.HEAD: Subdued Christmas Celebrations in Bethlehem, Violence in Gaza Strip
DOC.TEXT: Christians from around the world today prayed where tradition holds that Jesus was born, but the subdued Christmas was overshadowed by more violence in the 2-year-old Palestinian uprising. Israeli soldiers removed barricades and metal detectors from Manger Square after Christmas Eve passed quietly in this town in the occupied West Bank. Many troops also left the plaza during morning Mass. Violent clashes were reported in the Gaza Strip, where soldiers shot and wounded four Palestinians during stone-throwing protests in Jebalya refugee camp, Arab reports said. In Jerusalem, a firebomb was thrown at parked Israeli cars on a busy shopping street, causing no injury, and one Arab suspect was detained near the scene, police said. Desmond Tutu, the South African Anglican archbishop, worshiped at the Anglican St. George's church in Jerusalem's Arab sector. The 1984 Nobel Peace Prize winner has been criticized for repeatedly voicing sympathy with the Palestinians since his arrival in Israel Friday. Tutu's latest pro-Palestinian remarks came Sunday in a Christmas Eve sermon at Shepherd's Field near Bethlehem, the site where Jesus' birth was announced. ``We pray that Arabs and Jews will know that they are brother and sister, that they belong in one family, that they belong in God's family, that they belong in the human family. We support the struggle of the Palestinian people for nationhood,'' Tutu said. ``But we say also, dear brothers and sisters, the Jews have a right to their independent state as well,'' he said. Tutu's endorsement of a Palestinian state has alienated many Israelis, and the nation's two chief rabbis refused to meet with the Anglican human rights activist. Israeli media gave only sparse coverage to Tutu's visit. The Palestinian uprising was also the theme of a Christmas sermon given by Jerusalem's Roman Catholic patriarch, Michel Sabbah, at midnight mass in St. Catherine's basilica on Manger Square. ``How can we celebrate Christmas with what we are going through, with our sons killed or in prison?'' asked Sabbah, the first Arab appointed to his post. ``Despite all that is happening to you, you will win, in the end you will win. ``To the Jewish people, we say the same thing: love and forgiveness.'' Since the uprising began Dec. 8, 1987, at least 639 Palestinians have been killed and 43 Israelis have died.
